reviewText:
Grisaia no Kajitsu. It's my favorite visual novel.

The interface is great and comfortable, there is a good selection of Extras, like CGI and even Windows soundpacks and even icons. On a technical standpoint, it's a great game.

I may not have many hours on this (Unless a R-18 patch is released, or created by the users) - but I have played it.

Now with the story, it has its fair share of funny moments, and its fair share of dramatic moments..as well as those moments that had me on the brink of tears, or just depressed for multiple days.

Amane's route is outstanding. One issue in this version is that you're missing out on the adult content, which is coincidentally a large focus of her route. Though, there is also a lot of humor and fun in this version without any adult content. I will not spoil Amane's route at all because it's something that you truly have to experience for yourself. When I first played through her route, I only got 2 hours of sleep for 2 nights in a row, just because of how interested I was. It's amazing.

Sachi's route is very good, it's interesting finding out exactly what drives her to act as she does, just make sure that you are ready for the reason. Try not to get the bad ending for her, though..truly horrifying. I don't know fully how to put how I feel about her route into words, but I assure you that it's great. The R-18 content here does not matter as much, I believe- though in general I do believe that not having it is a general issue.

Yumiko's route is nice, she's sort of like a tsundere/kuudere mix in personality, and her route is generally good, but not exceptionally remarkable overall. I enjoyed her route a lot, especially in seeing how she slowly becomes close to you, or Yuuji. Nearing the end a lot of unexpected things happen, and it is all played out pretty well, but once again, when you compare it to something like Amane's route, it's hard to stand out. However, I still enjoyed it a lot.

I have not yet completed Makina's route, though it is pretty good so far. Lots of humor, and a lot of dark stuff as well. Each route has two sides, and they are all generally played out well. R-18 content here as far as I have gone doesn't matter at all, but I can't say for sure since I have not yet completed it.

I have not started Michiru's route, but some people argue that it is the best route in the entire game. Others argue that Amane's route is the best. They're generally the two most acclaimed in this game.

Overall, there was not a single moment in which I wanted to just get through a certain part to get to the good stuff so to speak. The entire experience was perfect, from the comedy to the pure horror at some points in time, everything was great. I do not have a single complaint for this game, but it goes without saying that the R-18 version is the definitive version to get.

If you're looking for an outstanding visual novel that will last you over 50 hours of gameplay-

(Yes, even with quick reading)

look no further than Grisaia no Kajitsu, or The Fruit of Grisaia""

*I played through all of the game with an offline version of the game*
Fruit of Grisaia is a visual NOVEL not a dating sim; you will be reading for hours before you make your first choice and another hour before you make your second choice. The story is a long and rambling account of a strange guy going to an obscure school of only five weird female students. Yes the setup is absurd, but Fruit of Grisaia knows it and goes with it.

As a novel I have to say how good the writing is since it is often thought provoking and emotionally touching. The problem is that those good moments are amongst a sea of silly-stupid encounters with those girls. That sillyness is fine if you like over-the-top Japanese cutesy schtick, but it's incredibly annoying if you don't. All the girls are to some degree frustrating-annoying with the Micharu girl being way off the scale. Michiru is so bad she is obnoxious. Makina is annoying but you later learn about her inner demons and why she is who she is. In fact, all of the main characters have their backstories developed wonderfully. Every character has their own genuine motives, wow. Micharu is still a pain in the ♥♥♥.

Other than the story: the art is lovely and each of the characters can be individually muted. Use the scroll wheel down to advance the story.

Overall I admit I like Fruit of Grisaia. I give it a 7 out of I-Don't-Do-Scores.

reviewText:
My friends hyped this visual novel to me to the point where it could no longer live up to my expectations. I was expecting writing up with the likes of Clannad and Little Busters.

That being said, it's still very good. I would say the character routes are, in fact, more intriguing and in-depth than the character routes from aforementioned visual novels by far.

First off, this visual novel does not have a true ending. The story leads somewhere entirely different based on which girl's route you choose. This is a very character-oriented visual novel.

Second, this visual novel does not have a lot of choice-making. The choices you have to make are pretty much limited to route branches and good/bad endings. While this is not a negative thing during the characters' routes, it could possibly have some impact on the very long common route if you are a person who would like to branch off into a character's route as soon as possible, or like to re-read parts of the common route and see what would happen if you made a different choice.

Third, the soundtrack is very good. Some visual novels tend to have a pretty forgettable soundtrack with the exception of a few major tracks (I'm looking at you, Sharin no Kuni, Himawari no Shoujo), but that is not the case with this one. It's one of those soundtracks where it's easy to hear that it belongs to The Fruit of Grisaia.

Fourth and last, the artwork is very pretty. The backgrounds and the CG are top quality. Couldn't ask for any improvements on those. After you complete a girls route you even unlock system voices, icons, and desktop wallpapers related to that character.

reviewText:
Grisaia no Kajitsu (グリザイアの果実) is the first game of the Grisaia trilogy. Originally released in 2011 in Nipland and developed by Frontwing, now one of the great Visual Novel is available in Steam! Thx based Sekai Project. It is one of the visual novel that requires your attention and interest in the medium because it's at least gonna waste around 50 hours of your time.

Is this VN worth your 50 hours tho? The answer is yes. Having already read the whole Grisaia trilogy and still buying Kajitsu on Steam after I finished reading it 3 years ago means I support the developer for their great work that is gone into making this game.

Grisaia no Kajitsu has a total of 5 routes for each heroine with their own bad ends and good ends. The five heroines are Suou Amane, Sakaki Yumiko, Komine Sachi, Matsushima Michiru & Irisu Makina. Each one of this heroine has their own distinctive persona and are interesting on their own. Of course each one of them has a problem, which is why the 5 of them goes to Mihama Academy in the first place. As for the MC, Kazami  Juicy  Yuuji is a bad-♥♥♥ based protagonist that has his own secret for coming to Mihama Academy. What's his problem for coming to Mihama Academy though is the biggest secret and it's pretty much driving power for the wild ride in the later Grisaia series (Meikyuu and Rakuen).

The story starts out slow and quite long. Actually tbh I enjoyed the common route more than the heroines route, whether that's a bad thing or a good thing I don't know. The jokes are funny and the heroine interaction with the MC and each other friend is quite lively. There aren't that many choices in the common route, because once a choice starts appearing, that means you're about to enter the heroine route and it's a long, long reading before you start seeing the choice. reviewText:
Warning: This review will only cover Makina’s Route in general as I have not done any of the other routes. There will also be minor spoilers ahead, you’ve been warned!
This VN is a story about a person who has had a very deep past about himself and his family. He gets enrolled to a “special” school where he meets 5 girls (I know, typical VN right?) and gets to know them better as the story progress further. You also get to know the story behind the girls, why they are in this school, their past etc. This is quite a unique style as most VNs have a style of “get the guy, forget everything else” thing, this VN actually puts you in a realistic environment as the Main Character (MC). All the girls have a different personality (Again, very typical here), but they are all very loveable and picking a route to complete can require some thought as it feel like you need to do all of them.

Okay for the actual features now
Graphics: 10/10
Overall artwork, design and CGI elements are all on point. The visuals themselves are very appealing to the eye, as you would see in the anime (If you’ve seen the anime). There is nothing else much to say…the art is just too good.

Storyline: 8/10
As I mentioned above, this will heavily focus more on Makina’s Route. As for the common route, this is just the stepping stone for getting to know the characters, the setting and the general story. It is very long and some chapters take a long time (Sometimes an hour) to be completed. Some of the chapters focus on each of the characters which is nice for getting to know them.
Now, as for Makina’s Route. It starts off as “This might actually go well for us” feeling until you get around chapter 8 of the route and realise that the situation is harder to handle than usual. This route is filled with a lot of in depth character perception and by this point a lot of character development as arisen, nice touch. JB, Makina’s Mother and The Irisu Clan are also heavily involved with this route as well as the MC A.K.A “9029” by the company he works for. The story does get a little complicated between the relation of Makina and the Irisu Clan, which made the entire route seem a little off. It also splits in a few parts in which it shouldn’t have, making it harder to understand than it already is. There is also a reason why Makina needs to be alive, but the clan wants her dead, but this reason wasn’t mentioned right until the end which was frustrating as it was such as important note.
There is a good and bad ending to this route (As well as in the other routes). Your choice at the end of the route will affect the ending, so save before choosing. I did manage to do both the good and the bad ending. The good ending, well as from the name, is “good” in a way. The bad ending however didn’t feel like a “bad” ending per se, it felt more like a “neutral” ending to be honest. But overall, this route was really solid and well made.

Sound: 9/10
Soundtracks including the OP theme, the menu soundtrack and the in-game scene soundtrack were very nice sounding, most were almost on point in the scene. It is not quite perfect as in some scenes (Tiny amount maybe only 4-5), they could’ve made better soundtracks in the situation. In this case it gets a solid score, very well done.

Gameplay: 9/10
It is a solidly built with all the features a VN would ever need, some are even beyond the boundaries of the VN like a feature to optimise up to 3 monitors, which is completely unnecessary, but great otherwise. There is the usual speed text slider which works absolutely fine, I did find the faster speeds still a little too slow, but they’re good enough as they are. You also have full voiced support (Except for the MC), you can turn them off if you wanted to, change the volume and turn off some and keep the others on (Great if you want to role-play) as one or more of the characters.
Unfortunately, the SHIFT + TAB feature doesn’t work as great, sometimes it opens, sometimes it doesn’t and sometimes it would slow down the game as if it was going to lag or about to crash, not a pleasant experience. I would suggest just using ALT +TAB is you want to switch between the game itself and something like a group chat, this way the game doesn’t get affect at all. This is VN, but for some reason idle FPS is usually around 25-30 FPS, I don’t know why, but this value should be at 60 FPS, not 25-30 FPS. Not saying it doesn’t reach 60 FPS, it does, but only when you are constantly reading, but even if you leave it idling for 5 seconds, it would dip down to 25 FPS at the lowest.

Price: 10/10
Just look at my hours on this VN…It costs £30 and you can probably get it on sale for around £20 or less if you’re lucky. This is totally worth it, no doubts about that one. Took me 61 hours to finish ONE ROUTE, yes ONE ROUTE!! That should tell you a lot. So, if you are planning to finish all the routes, you’ll definitely get your money’s worth here. This is a must buy for the person out there willing to spend the time on reading all the chapters and finishing all the routes.

End of Review

tl;dr press buy, get happiness #moist

Definitely one of the best visual novels out right now, this is the first of three visual novels that Sekai Project is aiming to release within 2015. Already having completed this game pre-Steam release, this is probably the visual novel I'd recommend to anyone looking for a (long) ride to enjoy. Oh, and yes, everything except for the main character is voiced. And done beautifully, at that.

In the story you take the role as the main character, Kazami Yuuji. He's a cool guy, always knows what to do and seems to be experienced in most things in life already. Currently attending this school while having a chain tied to his neck from the government. So what's up with this guy? After a bit of trouble in the start you make your way to the academy where you will be staying with 5 other girls, each with their unique traits: A maid, a ♥♥♥♥, a loli, a tsundere and an anti-social crazy boxcutter girl. All of these girls are in this academy because of the same reason as you - there's something in their past that makes them ♥♥♥♥ed up. After an entertaining common route, you get to delve deep into one of the girls backstory. They are drama-filled, funny and contain action as well. And some romance. And porn (well, not here unfortunately). Even if you are not a very emotional person, I can almost assure you it will bring a tear to your eye or at least make your heart sink. Unfortunately I believe Sekai took out the H-scenes from this release, which were amazingly well done. Anyway little by little you'll see Yuuji's backstory unfold, and by the end you'll want more. That's where the sequel game swoops in and serves you the full story, before the third game takes you back to the present with some mindblowing action and excitement.

The OST of this visual novel is absolutely fantastic. The songs playing throughout the game helps set a good mood, and the ending songs can be very heartbreaking. One thing to notice that might be different from many other visual novels is the lack of choices here. You don't get awfully many. You will play many hours without seeing a choice. There are some, though. However this is not necessarily a bad thing. This visual novel wants to tell you a great story, however your ability to influence it is limited. You will influence it, and the outcome of it, but not as much as many people would probably wish for. Furthermore due to the different personality of the girls, you're guaranteed to find one you like. Whether it's one of the academy girls, JB, Asako, Kazuki or even the principal.

Pros
- Engaging and rich story
- Funny -  I tried to capture images of many of the funny scenes but there were too many and it was pointless cause at that point I'd just reveal the entire game to whoever I showed it so they might as well just play it themselves. Yes, it's that much.

- Beautiful OST
- Good art
- Lots of on-screen effects (both visual and sounds) to enhance reading experience
- hot grils


Cons

- The game is ♥♥♥♥ING long. Whether this is a good or a bad thing is up to you. Considering how much I enjoyed the game, this is definitely good for me. I have, however, recommended this game to a lot of people that don't want to give it a go because it packs probably 80+ hours of gameplay (all routes) if you do not try to speed-read through it. Most of these people say they'd rather watch the 13-episode anime. Yeah, 13 episodes, it's pretty much bound to be a failure trying to fit all this gameplay into 13 episodes.

Now as I haven't played through this translation of the game yet, I can't comment on the translation. I will eventually though, I guess. I know that the localization of The Labyrinth of Grisaia is in progress and I'm very much excited for when it will come out.

Pros:
-Since this is a VN, let's get the most important bit out of the way first. The writing in this game, while it takes it a bit to get started, is absolutely PHENOMENAL. Each of the character arcs is handled incredibly well. Each of the five characters are thought through and are very interesting character studies. Not to mention, the way the character personalities clash is often hilarious. It's to the extent that I've found myself contemplating some plot points or speculating about possible upcoming events while at work or on my commute.
-On the note of writing, I've gotta give major props to the writers that handled the translation. The amount of vocabulary that I've learned from this game exceeds most natively english titles. There were even times when I saw a word, thought it was a typo, looked it up, and learned that it was an actual word. Well done.
-This game doesn't fall into the pit trap of having copy/pasted narratives. Yes, there's some similar themes that happen on occasion, but I was pleased to see that each of the paths is basically unique and even each of the endings is distinctly different.

reviewText:
SPOILER FREEFor starters, please do not pay full retail price. I would find it very hard to justify when for example I got it on a 50% sale.

My Thoughts:I personally loved this game from every point. This game will drive you down every road for each character which I felt was very effective at truly making you decide who you love and want to go for. This game has five main characters excluding the player, however there are ten endings. Each character has one good ending and one bad ending which really gives the game some replay value. Each character has a very interesting unique personality from each other.
One of the key things I found very interesting about this game was the developer’s decision to make scenes focus on all the girls just talking about a random topic. For example, which room they should have dinner in or what they should call each other even though the player isn’t talking in those scenes but rather sitting aside. I felt this gave very true character development.
What could have been better:The story is very long. In fact, probably the longest visual novel I’ve ever read. However, it contains the same amount of player choices as for example a six-hour visual novel would have. Because of this, I felt there was huge gaps in between the player choices which lead to me feeling as if it was linear. Personally, I like the ability to decide my own future within the story to a relatively advance degree saying that the retail price is exceptionally high compared to other visual novels.
Would I recommend:YES! By far this is my favorite visual novel. However, if you intend to get this game please don’t pay full retail. It’s not even remotely justifiable. But with that said everything is amazing from the unique characters to the way they’re represented within the visual novel.

reviewText:
One of the better Visual Novel currently available on Steam
When looking for good Visual Novels, Steam is unfortunately often not the right place. Most of the VNs available there are rather geared towards heavy fan-service (not to say Grisaia has none) and usually aren't really good overall when compared to other ones - as can be seen from their score on VNDB (Visual Novel Database).

That being said Grisaia is one of the few exception, hopefully soon to be joined by Muv Luv as well. The story is entertaining, you easily get attached to the characters and for once the protagonist isn't your typical blank canvas - if anything he is very un-japanese in his behavior, which is a breath of fresh air in a Visual Novel.

For those who don't know what a Visual Novel is, it's fairly simple. Just imagine reading a book, with images and music to set the mood and atmosphere. On top of that, sprinkle a few choices you can make as a reader to turn the story towards what you want it to become. Note that in most Visual Novels, different routes are drastically different from one another (it isn't an illusion of choice" like in The Walking Dead for instance).

reviewText:
this is gonna be really messy and probably a terribly written review, but hopefully I get my point across.

There are 3 reasons as to why I bought Grisaia on steam.
1. I love the series.
2. To support the people that made it.
3. To write a review telling you that you should buy it too.

I've read this VN once before with the unofficial translation, and absolutely fell in love with it to the point where I wanted to do whatever I could to support it when available. I ended up purchasing a Japanese psp version of the game, and now this one, and I plan to buy it again when DenpaSoft releases the unrated version(oh boy, h scenes!!). This VN stands as one of my favorite VNs and stories overall, only beaten out by Muv Luv Alternative.

The characters in this story are all really well done. They are extremely enjoyable, and if you don't like one of the characters, you're bound to like another.
Yuuji is a fantastic protagonist, who manages to be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and a sweetheart all at the same time, in some manner.
Amane is the onee-san type role, and absolutely fantastic. Her route has a bit of a boring spot but quickly picks up and is one of my favorites in the game.
Michiru wants to be your run of the mill tsundere but manages to be a very interesting character.
Sachi is a maid who does what everyone says.
Makina's the loli/imouto type, and I'm not too interested in her but her route is fantastic, probably the best in the game.
And Yumiko is your violent kuudere, similar to Senjougahara from the monogatari series.
There is a lot more to each character, and a reason they act the way they do, but if I were to say more I'd spoil all the fun.

The story is absolutely fantastic, but if I were to go on about it, I'd probably end up spoiling it for you so I don't want to say anything, but there's plenty of good twists and events within the VN to really keep you interested.

There isn't a whole lot of choices to make in this vn. A few filler choices in shared route, and then 2 choices per route(One to get on each route, and one to decide the ending).

The one thing to keep in mind when reading this vn, is that it is extremely long(VNDB states about 50+ hours). The shared route goes on for quite some time.

This VN is definitely worth the cost, and I recommend it to anyone who enjoys VNs, or anime.
If you watched the Grisaia anime, the VN is a must, as the anime doesn't nearly compare to how good the VN is.

As I said earlier, if you'd rather wait for an uncensored version with more anime boob, DenpaSoft is also going to be releasing one at a later currently unannounced date.

reviewText:
I'm going to be frank about this. Grisaia no Kajitsu is painfully average in many regards. Let the fanboys pour their hate upon me, yet I shall still hold my position. The game suffers from some of the worst pacing I have ever experienced, only being topped by that of Hoshizora no Memoria. Ive tried to like this, as can be shown by my playtime. I was almost never idle when I was playing. Yet, I feel disappointed. About 70% of the entire game is filler. It is full of bland and boring dialogue,  with uninventive slice of life scenes. So far, i've only completed 2 routes, and i'm on my 3rd. Yet I have continuously found it difficult to keep forcing myself through the dull happenings that constantly plague the story just to get to the meat of the game.

Ive heard many people praise the game for exploring the backgrounds and psyches of the characters, and it does live up to that expectation. However, you have to get through 40 hours of sleep-inducing dialogue and repetitive events. Its simply not worth it unless you have a ♥♥♥♥ ton of patience. Granted, even that probably wont be enough. Ive played around 20 visual novels, 7 of which take around 20-50 hours to complete. However, those visual novels contained something this one does not. An interesting plot. The plot is entirely non-existent, only focusing on character exploration of each heroine. The common route is merely 30 hours of filler. Its absolutely mind numbingly boring.

All in all, this game was a disappointment to me. I picked it up on its release date when it was being hyped up by a ♥♥♥♥ ton of people. If theres anything I can thank this visual novel for, its getting me into the meat of the genre. However, I can not recommend this. Buy this if you are looking for a game ENTIRELY character-driven, as that is all you will get. If you are trying to find a thought-provoking or engaging story, I would recommend G Senjou no Maou.

Edit 1: The heroine routes are pretty good, I will admit. The flashback scenes hold quite a bit of tension during them, and keeps you hooked the entire time (unlike the rest of the game). Even so, I don't think it's worth it to have to go through the utterly mediocre and bland common route. Many people say that the reason that Grisaia is so great is because of its comedy and its characters. While its characters are where it shines, and they are quite complex, that is simply no excuse for the lack of plot focus in the game. It feels like the writer should have spent more time focusing on creating a compelling story rather than dragging the game out with filler.

Some of the scenes tugged at my heartstrings, but they left no lasting impression. In regards to the comedy, it might just not be for me. I honestly tried to enjoy the slice of life elements, but they just aren't that great. The comedy falls flat, and just doesn't compare to legitimately funny and gripping VNs like Majikoi Oh Samurai Girls. I will admit that I am judging this game harshly, but I truly did enjoy many parts of it. I do think this is one of the best VNs on steam, but I can't wholeheartedly recommend it with its flaws. Hence why I made a negative review instead of a positive review.

Edit 2: Alright, so I have currently finished Sakaki's route, and am now on Makina's. While I felt that Amane and Michiru's routes were quite dull, I found Sakaki's route to be much better. It started out very dull and boring, but ended up being quite good in the end. I don't wish to spoil it, but I honestly preferred it much more over Amane and Michiru's routes. Makina's route so far is quite cute in all honesty, and I think that she might be my favorite out of all of them. Also, it seems like the majority of Yuuji's (Protagonist) backstory is revealed in this route, making it much more interesting. I'm still not going to give this game a positive review as I feel that more people would see this if it was in the negative reviews rather than positive, and I have not seen any other reviews shed light on the game's issues.

I would recommend this game hesitantly ONLY to someone looking for slice of life with a bit of tragedy mixed in (definitely don't look for a compelling overall story, as that is not what you will get).

reviewText:
One of the best visual novel games to date, Grisaia no Kajitsu aka The Fruit of Grisaia was a very enjoyable playthrough, with many heartfelt moments and fantastically well written characters.

The story follows our main protagonist Yuuji Kazami, who has been admitted into a private school for students who can't function well in modern society due to the tragic events that happen to them when they were younger. Kazami quickly learns that he is the sixth student to have started to attend a school and that his other classmates are all of the opposite gender.

Yuuji's classmates consist of a cute little ball of energy named Makina Irisu, who has a noticable lisp in her voice when she speaks do to having a very small tongue. Makina is usually intimidated by people she just meant and usually hids behind her bestfriend/older sister figure Amane Suou.

Upon opening up to someone, Makina shows her more troublemaking side and loves to use the fact that she is small and adorable to get her way with just about anyone who she is comfortable with.

Makina's tramatic past has to deal with her rich family background that is just as amazingly well-written as it is sad. A mother who has abandoned her and screws around with other men.

Yuuji's next classmate is a fake-tsundere by the name of Michiru Matsushima. Michiru has conciously decided to act as the token tsundere archtype, although it is pretty easily to tell that it is forced. Michiru tries to empress others with her tsundere act, although most of the time she fails horribly due to the fact that she is a massive klutz, but at the same time she is very sweat and cares about her friends dearly.

Michiru trama is rooted in an accident that she was a victim of and she suffers from an identity crisis that has nothing to do with her fake-tsundere persona, but is so bad that she is almost suicidal.

The best girl is Sachi Komine, a girl with a passion for the maid lifestyle and an unhealthy obsession with helping others. Sachi is the first girl you will speak to upon entering the school as she is very suspicious of you being an intruder.

Sachi takes on the role from a class rep, who will take on any request no matter how ridiculous it may be. Sachi also has shown many times throughout your run to be someone who takes every way too seriously and has a serious weird catchphrase when someone has to explain something to her when she either has the wrong idea or just being weird.

Sachi loves being praised by others, mostly the main character and adores it when you pet her on the head. She also has a weird obsession with expecting you to do perverted things to her or the other girls and has a slight masochistic nature to her personality.

Sachi's trama deals with the fact that she is convinced that she was the cast for the people in her life disappearing and so she will do anything anyone tells her to in the hopes that she has to never again experience the pain that she went through as a child.

The next girl is Sakaki Yumiko, the daughter of the person who is currently funding the school that they all attend. Yumiko is at first very hostile towards the main male character and likes to keep her distance from other, preferring to spend most of the day in her room when not attending class.

Yumiko is a menace, always caring around a box cutter blade to threaten anyone who approaches her, due to her paranoia.

Much like Makina, Yumiko's issues have to deal with her family, being the daughter of a Wealthy businessman, who treats her like a pawn for him to use when he feels the need to and how her fathers cold personality affected her and her now dead mother.

Last but not least, we have Amane Suou, the big sister character who absolutely adores the main character, play the role of the horny big sister character with large breasts.

Amane is almost a enigma as she is quite shocked when Yuuji introduces himself as if she knows something about him, but never says anything.

She quickly latches on to the main male lead, using her feminine charms and large assets to gain Yuuji's affection. she is very aggressive in the aspect of romance and is not afraid to fault her body to the point where even being naked in front of Yuuji does not embarrass her all that much.

At the same time she is very shy with simple affectionate actions shared between loves. (like kissing)

Amane always has an upbate expression on her face and loves to make dirty jokes when around Yuuji, that may in fact not be jokes depending on her mood. She also sometimes has a sultry grin on her face when she is trying to seduce Yuuji who usually brushes her off due to being a big tsundere himself.

Amane is charged with taking care of Makina playing the motherly role for the girl, which is best better than some people twice her age.

she is an exceptional cook having been raised in the kitchen at her families restaurant and has a passion for driving since she got her license.

That being said Amane also has her tragic past to deal with that she can't seem to escape from. Amane trauma deal with Societies need for a scapegoat to focus all their hatred and sorrow upon, and her own self imposed atonement for something that she had no power over and the trauma of being the lone survivor of an tragic event that took the lives of many.

It is up to Yuuji  to help each of these five girls overcome the tragic past and find a place where they belong and find a place where a broken weapon like him can belong and find love.

This is a truly great story that I recommend you buy and experience as soon as possible.

Truly 9/10 work.

It's a pure VN with little choice and hours upon hours of the character's daily lives and the sometimes hilarity that ensues.  The game has a distinct Japanese, comedy-anime style setting and takes place at a secluded school for societal rejects, essentially.  The thing that made me stop was, honestly, the main character, who is just cliche' and unlikable.  He's an ex-military prodigy with zero social skills, constant PTSD, and he loves to lecture everyone like he's their mom.  He is surrounded by five hot anime chicks who have varying levels of interest in him, but rather than set out to have sex with them (which is what I would do if I was the protagonist of a hentai game!), he constantly teases and berates them.  The girls' personalities, similarly, are unidimensional, and it's clear why they can't function in regular society, but ultimately this is where the humor comes from.  I'm sure some people will love the game, but for me, I have to draw the line and admit that I just didn't like it.

reviewText:
Grisaia no Kajitsu is a well rounded, quality vn with good art, good ost and likable characters. The vn is the first of three popular visual novels in Japan that are planned to be brought to the west. My playthrough including every ending took me 60 hours with me reading at a fairly leisurely pace, so there is a fair amount of content to keep you satisfied. Unfortunately, as you can expect, sex scenes were cut for the steam release but there is an uncensored version and I'm sure you can figure out how to read the vn uncensored if you care about it enough to, I personally found it great even without them.

The main cast of girls have a good spread of personalities, each with a bit more depth than it might first appear.
In the most basic terms, there is a fun loving imouto type character, a caring if lecherous onee-san type, a maid who obeys any request, a borderline shut in who might be a bit on the paranoid side and a genius comperable to Cirno who tries her best to be a tsundere. The mc and side characters are also good, and help keep every hour you are reading enjoyable even during early segments that build atmosphere and character relationships through slice of life.

While Grisaia is mostly slice of life every main girl has a hefty load of problems that they will have to deal with in their route and some of it can get fairly dicey. The vn has a great balance of serious tone and enjoyable every day life to it that can make you very attached to the characters and involved in what happens to them later on in the vn.
TLDR: If you are looking for a vn on steam, you can be sure that Grisaia is probably some of the best steam has to offer. It is a little pricy for some, but if you can catch it on sale I would definately reccomend buying it if you are interested.

reviewText:
I often read Visual Novels, and I must admit that this one was pretty good. If not my favorite for now.
I related a lot to the main character: being somewhat without any purpose in life, cynical, detached from everything. Even if he somewhat lack of social skills, and how to deal with these girls.
About the girls: they seemed to have a rich background and interesting personalities.

This visual novel is very humor oriented, and it's true that's sometimes it becomes annoying. But besides that, the story is very well written, with a touch of poesy and vivid descriptions of sensory experiences.

The art style is awesome, there's a lot of different interactions and illustrations for a visual novel. Some music are awesome, and some are somewhat mediocre. So I'm a bit reserved about it.

But the quality of the dialogues, and interactions between characters are absolutely awesome. I think that I will rarely found such quality elsewhere.

(I've only finished one path, but there wasn't any explicit erotic scene, and I must admit that it is better that way. I prefer when this type of content is implicit. I've not done all paths though.)

What can I add? The beginning can look long, but in the end it's worth it. The story is growing like a flower, slowly but it is beautiful. Full of intelligence and humor. The author have a lot of imagination, and shows us that even happiness can be reached with such anodyne things in life. And that we can understand each point of view, because if someone behave a certain way, there is a reason to such a behavior.

The price is certainly what makes me buy it, because I was really surprised that a VN could be so expensive. But know I understand this fact. And it is somewhat justified. If you want to read a VN, I really recommend this one.

reviewText: Easily one of the best visual novels to date. In my opinion it probably is the best. reviewText:
When I started seeing screenshots of this game years ago, I knew I had to experience the entirety of The Fruit of Grisaia.

After that, I watched the anime hoping to grasp clearly what the fuss was about. I enjoyed what I saw, but I felt like too much was missing from the original novel. I wanted more.

I came to this visual novel expecting a funny, lighthearted at times experience complemented with jokes that could make anyone laugh, but also deathly serious in some situations. I expected each character to just come across as another archetype in different circumstances.

Two endings in (Michiru and Yumiko), and I have realized how gravely I had underscored this novel.

From tackling powerful topics, such as depression and suicide, and giving each character a truly memorable personality, Grisaia no Kajitsu is without a doubt an experience unlike any other. The ways that each character embrace their unusual" circumstances are worthy of earnest praise and commendation
date: and every victory and defeat that affects them affects the player just as much.\n\nSome people will equate this game as simply another eroge in the market and will lament that this is "the censored shell of the original"
recommended: but perhaps it is because of the removal of the h-scenes that allows one to appreciate the story behind those acts of affection. To simply read through this game to alleviate one's desires would be a massive disrespect to the true nature of this novel
hoursPlayed: in my opinion.\n\nThe Fruit of Grisaia is an experience like no other. Time and again

reviewText: We need more of THESE kinds of VNs on steam. And by that I mean VNs that take longer than 10+ hours per route. I'm tired of all of these VNs making me shell out $20 for a four hour experience. I'm 10 hours in this VN so far, and still not finished, so kudos to whatever company made this. The main reason I'm tired is because I've been playing VNs most of my life, and they used to be a fantastic experience every time, because they were always long enough that I didn't need to worry what I was paying for. NOW, I can't rest easy until I know for sure the VN is at the very least 10 hours a route. So to all of these companies releasing two hour long VNs, please stop. I want to get immersed in the characters, not watch a feature film. It's hard for me to care when it just stops abruptly and I somehow get an ending with the 2 total choices that I made.

reviewText: I watched the amine for the first time a few weeks ago. Thought it was really good. I found out that it was based on a VN, but I didn't want to download a virus-filled, buggy version. The choices for the girls are few, so to get set on a certain lady's path doesn't take much, but considering it's a 20 hour game per route, you will probably not complain much about the choices. I enjoy this game and would recommend it to anyone seeking a quality VN or for fans of the anime.
